issue.title: MkContents.update() should create a commit and handle branches

repository.name: jcabi-github
repository.description: Java Object-Oriented Wrapper of GitHub API, with a fake implementation of the entire GitHub API (for your tests)

issue.body: I think `MkContents.update()` should create a commit in addition to file update. Also, it should handle branches. See http://developer.github.com/v3/repos/contents/#update-a-file. Looks like this issue depends on #434.

body: thanks for reporting, looks like a bug
What do you think would be a good way to return both objects for update? Shall we return a `Map` containing `content` and `commit` keys?
I think we should return a commit. Content is known to the users, since he is changing it. But commit is something completely new.

@yegor256 of course, done already

@longtimeago many thanks for your contribution, I just added 15 mins to your account (ID: `36498332`)
@carlosmiranda it's your task now, the budget is **30 mins**
What about the `create` operation as mentioned by @longtimeago ? Perhaps that is better off as a separate ticket?

Another question - seems to me that, as part of the Repos API, shouldn't the `Content` operations be returning `RepoCommit` instead of `Commit`? `Commit` is part of the Git Data API while `RepoCommit` is part of the Repos API. In this case I think `update` should return a `RepoCommit` instance instead of `Commit`.

If you agree, then `remove` should also return `RepoCommit`, which we can file as a separate issue.
Yes, I agree about `RepoCommit`. And the same for `remove`
@yegor256 All right, I'll address the `update` method since it's addressed by this ticket; meanwhile I created a new issue for the `remove` method at #593.
